Award.AwardTitle: Volatile Clues to the Initial Controls on Large Explosive Volcanic Eruptions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to better understand how large explosive volcanic eruptions start and the timescales (days or weeks or more) of precursory activity that might serve as a warning sign of an impending eruption. Enormous explosive eruptions (known as supereruptions) have occurred in the recent geologic past that are many times larger than any eruptions that have taken place in historic times. Some of the best and youngest examples, at Yellowstone, in eastern California, and in New Zealand will be studied in this project. A primary goal is to determine if external factors, like an earthquake and movement along a fault, can cause such eruptions to start, or whether instead, they start when a magma body in the earth?s crust becomes overpressured and bursts, like a ruptured balloon. The project will involve chemical analysis of ash and pumice deposits that were created during the opening stages of the eruptions because these preserve a record of information about how and why the eruptions started and how long it took for magma to move to the Earth's surface.

This project will test some fundamental ideas about how large explosive rhyolitic eruptions start and when caldera collapse occurs. Despite many important advances in modeling of these processes, there is a surprising lack of geochemical data on the very earliest deposits from large explosive eruptions that could inform the debate about eruption triggering. A quantitative record of magma decompression and ascent rates shortly before and during the opening stages of these eruptions will be obtained by measuring concentrations and gradients of volatiles (H2O, CO2, Cl, S, F) in melt inclusions and reentrants (unsealed inclusions) in quartz and the OH contents of plagioclase. Because magma ascent rates reflect the extent of overpressure in the underlying magma body, constraining ascent rates for the earliest materials from an eruption using diffusive loss of volatiles can provide insight into whether internal (magma overpressure) or external (little or no overpressure) triggers were involved. Based on preliminary results for the Huckleberry Ridge fall deposit (Yellowstone), such data appear to provide a unique record of the processes and timescales of vent development just prior to and during the opening phases of an eruption, with implications for when and why caldera collapse develops and how magma bodies were configured in the upper crust. The results of this investigation will provide quantitative information about how rapidly supereruptions begin and will contribute data to models of geophysical signals that could precede them. This project involves collaborations with other scientists in the U.S. and New Zealand for some of the specialized chemical analyses that will be done and for computer modeling using the results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the geologic past, there have been rare but extremely large explosive eruptions (known as supereruptions) of rhyolitic magma that formed huge calderas and devastated large areas with volcanic material. Such catastrophic events have occurred on Earth roughly once every 100,000 to 200,000 years. We studied the deposits from three such eruptions to investigate what caused the eruptions to start (and in some cases to start and stop multiple times), and how fast magma moved towards the surface from the underground regions where it was stored at high temperature before eruption. The eruptions we investigated were: (1) the Oruanui eruption in New Zealand (25.4 thousand years ago), (2) the Bishop Tuff/Long Valley Caldera eruption in eastern California (767 thousand years ago), and (3) the Huckleberry Ridge eruption at Yellowstone (2.1 million years ago). We focused on the very first material (volcanic ash and pumice) that was erupted from these events in order to find clues as to how the eruptions started. 

We combined geochemical analysis of crystals from the ash deposits with computer models to reveal how rapidly magma moved towards the surface during the opening stages of each eruption. One important discovery from our work was that initial magma movement towards the surface in the Oruanui and Huckleberry Ridge eruptions was fairly slow and took place over days to several weeks before any actual explosive eruptions began at the surface. The characteristics of the volcanic deposits also show evidence that the eruptions started and stopped multiple times, with eruptive pauses on the order of days to weeks (Huckleberry) to as long as months (Oruanui). 

The slow ascent of magma and the starting and stopping of eruptions provides valuable information on what caused the eruptions to start. One process commonly thought to cause eruptions to start is the build-up of gas pressure in the magma at depth, like what would happen in a pressure cooker that eventually becomes overpressurized and then explosively ruptures. But this process would cause magma to ascend very rapidly and cannot explain the start-stop nature of the eruptions. Instead, our results provide evidence that some external factor was at work in triggering the Oruanui and Huckleberry Ridge eruptions to begin, such as a change in tectonic stresses in the Earth’s crust around the magma body, as might result from a large earthquake. For the Huckleberry Ridge and Oruanui eruptions, the 1 to 2 week timescale of magma ascent that we found for the very first erupted material represents the minimum time frame over which there might have been detectable signals that an eruption would soon begin, which is useful information for monitoring of volcanically active regions. 

We found a very different result for the Bishop Tuff/Long Valley Caldera eruption. There we found that magma at the start of the eruption ascended to the surface in less than a day, consistent with field evidence for continuous, escalating activity during the initial stages of the eruption and no stopping or pauses. This points to a different eruption triggering process, likely involving build-up of internal gas pressure, as described above. Overall, our research on these three eruptions showed how complex the opening stages of a large eruption can be, and highlight that each eruption must be studied in detail to reveal how and why the eruption began.

There were several interrelated projects that were supported by this grant. The work on the projects was done by two graduate students and two undergraduates at the University of Oregon. The grant also involved a collaboration with researchers at James Madison University, where five undergraduate students worked on various aspects of the project. Most of the undergraduate students at both universities went on to pursue graduate education. Their work supported by this grant was an invaluable research experience for them as they get started on their scientific careers.
